Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Advancing Environmental Equity Research: Vulnerability to Air Pollution and Flood Risks in Houston and Miami

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project aims to address several limitations associated with current environmental justice research and practice, and advance knowledge of social and spatial influences on residential exposure to environmental hazards. The research involves parallel analyses of two high-impact hazards (air pollution and flooding) conducted in the two largest urban areas on the U.S. Gulf Coast: Houston, Texas and Miami, Florida. Key questions to be investigated include: How do factors such as risk mitigation, locational benefits, and household decision-making processes, which have received little attention in environmental justice research, influence relationships between social vulnerability and hazard exposure? How do hazard attributes and contextual factors influence relationships between social vulnerability and hazard exposure? A quantitative phase of research will integrate data from a social survey of 1,000 households with neighborhood level data to examine multilevel determinants of hazard exposure. A qualitative phase will rely on interviews with a subset of survey participants to provide insight into decision-making processes that underpin patterns of hazard exposure. A comparative phase will replicate analyses for multiple air pollution and flood risk variables to specify the influence of hazard attributes (e.g., frequency/magnitude, suddenness of onset) on spatial relationships between social vulnerability and hazard exposure. A final contextual phase will analyze each city's historical geography to facilitate explanation of differences in findings between the study sites. The project will provide a comparative, multilevel, multi-method framework for modeling residential exposure to environmental hazards, and transform current understandings of factors contributing to environmental and social injustices.

The results of the project will enhance public knowledge of environmental risks, inform practitioner communities, contribute to education, and increase the participation of underrepresented groups in hazards research and practice. Education and research training opportunities will be provided to students from underrepresented groups. Project data and findings will be disseminated via multiple outlets in English and Spanish. Partnerships with the Houston and Miami geographic education communities will be formed and project data and results will be translated into learning modules for use in high school geography classrooms. Finally, press releases will ensure broad utilization of project data and products, which will be made accessible via a project website.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The research literature of environmental justice (EJ) encompasses a wide range of case studies that seek to determine whether environmental risk burdens are unequally distributed with respect to racial/ethnic minorities and low-income groups. This collaborative project aimed to address several limitations associated with EJ research and practice, and advance knowledge of social and spatial influences on residential exposure to environmental hazards. The research involved parallel analyses of two high-impact hazards--air pollution and flooding--conducted in the largest urban areas on the U.S. southeastern coast: Houston, Texas, and Miami, Florida. Key questions investigated include: How do factors such as actions taken to reduce risks (e.g., elevating the home to protect against flooding), benefits associated with the home's location, and household decision-making process, which have received little attention in EJ research, influence relationships between social disadvantage and hazard exposure? How do hazard attributes and contextual factors influence relationships between social disadvantage and hazard exposure? A quantitative phase of research analyzed data from a social survey of more than 1,200 randomly selected households as well as neighborhood level data to examine determinants of hazard exposure. A qualitative phase relied on interviews with a subset of more than 90 survey participants to provide insight into decision-making processes that lead to hazard exposure. A comparative phase replicated analyses for multiple air pollution and flood risk variables to specify the influence of hazard attributes (e.g., divisibility benefits from risks, frequency/magnitude, suddenness of onset) on spatial relationships between social disadvantage and hazard exposure. A final contextual phase analyzed results in reference to each city's particular features to support explanation of differences in findings between the study sites.

In terms of intellectual merit, the project provided a comparative, multi-method framework for examining residential exposure to environmental hazards, and offered novel insights into factors contributing to environmental injustices. Based on our sample of Houston and Miami households, we found that residents in both locales exhibit awareness of the high local levels of air pollution and flood exposure, but that for many, those concerns have not influenced their residential decision-making. Avoiding air pollution and flood risks was less influential than finding housing with desirable features and surrounding amenities when households selected their homes. Given the high levels of risk they face, households have generally undertaken relatively few actions to protect themselves against disasters, floods/hurricanes, and air pollution, which indicates that they could be more active in taking steps in mitigating risks. Additionally, we found complex social patterns of exposure to air pollution and flood risks. For air pollution, we found that social disadvantage (e.g., Black or Hispanic race/ethnicity, low socioeconomic status) was generally associated with increased risk, although relationships for Hispanic country-of-origin and nativity (U.S. vs. foreign-born) subgroups as well as interactions between race/ethnicity and other characteristics exhibited complexities that have not been previously examined. For flood risk, we found that social disadvantage (e.g., white-Anglo race/ethnicity, higher property values) was associated with increased risk in coastal areas, while social disadvantage was associated with increased risk in inland locations. These seemingly contradictory findings are largely attributable to the indivisibility of water-based benefits from flood risks in coastal or beach front contexts, and the relatively low levels of water-based benefits in flood-prone inland contexts. Findings indicate that hazard attributes (especially the divisibility of benefits from risks associated with the hazard) play an important, previously overlooked role in structuring spatial relationships between social status and hazard exposure.

In terms of broader impacts, project outcomes include enhanced public knowledge of environmental risks and increased participation of individuals from underrepresented backgrounds in hazards research and practice. Project data and findings were disseminated via multiple outlets. Analyses provided the basis for 16 published articles in high-tier scholarly journals such as Risk Analysis and Annals of the American Association of Geographers (with 3 additional manuscripts under time at the time of reporting), as well as 28 presentations at national/international conferences and invited colloquia. Results flyers summarizing project finding and information on locally-relevant risk reduction resources were provided to all study participants in Houston and Miami, in both English and Spanish. Results of the research were also publicly disseminated via more than 50 news media outlets. Funded education and research training opportunities were provided to graduate and undergraduate students--all of whom are from traditionally underrepresented groups--at the University of Texas at El Paso and the University of South Florida. The project funded 10 student trainees, providing the basis for 1 completed PhD dissertation, 2 completed Master's theses, and 8 undergraduate research experiences. Student trainees co-authored 13 of the 19 project-related manuscripts and 19 of the 28 presentations. All student trainees graduated from their respective degree programs, and the project has provided a STEM career springboard for 8 student trainees who have matriculated into Master's and doctoral programs, and postdoctoral research positions.
